pageTitle: Cisco Nexus 7000 Series NX-OS Security Configuration Guide, Release 5.x - Configuring SSH and Telnet [Cisco Nexus 7000 Series Switches] - Cisco
TableContextTimeStampBeforeTable: {864=By default, the Cisco NX-OS software generates an RSA key using 1024 bits.}

textBeforeTable: DETAILED STEPS 7.    (Optional) copy running-config startup-config 6.    (Optional) show ssh key 5.    exit 4.    feature ssh 3.    ssh key {dsa [force] | rsa [bits [force]]} 2.    no feature ssh 1.    configure terminal SUMMARY STEPS You can generate an SSH server key based on your security requirements. The default SSH server key is an RSA key that is generated using 1024 bits. Generating SSH Server Keys Clearing SSH Sessions Deleting SSH Server Keys Disabling the SSH Server Clearing SSH Hosts Configuring SCP and SFTP Servers Configuring SSH Passwordless File Copy Starting SSH Sessions from Boot Mode Starting SSH Sessions Configuring a Maximum Number of SSH Login Attempts Specifying the SSH Public Keys for User Accounts Generating SSH
textAfterTable: Step 3 ssh key {dsa [force] | rsa [bits [force]]} Example: switch(config)# ssh key rsa 2048   Generates the SSH server key. The bits argument is the number of bits used to generate the RSA key. Beginning with Cisco NX-OS Release 5.1, the range is from 1024 to 2048. In Cisco NX-OS Release 5.0, the range is from 768 to 2048. The default value is 1024. You cannot specify the size of the DSA key. It is always set to 1024 bits. Use the force keyword to replace an existing key.   Step 4 feature ssh Example: switch(config)# feature ssh   Enables SSH.   Step 5 exit Example: switch(config)# exit switch#   Exits global configuration mode.   Step 6 show ssh key Example: switch# show ssh key   (Optional) Displays the SSH server keys.   Step 7 copy running-config startup-config
